Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large:Collaborative Research: Context-Driven Management of Heterogeneous Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) composed of smart sensors interconnected over wireless links are quickly becoming the technology of choice for monitoring and measuring geographically distributed physical, chemical, or biological phenomena in real time. Dynamic WSN environments encountered in environmental monitoring, surveillance, pollution control, and reconnaissance applications, require responsive management of WSN resources and their adaptive allocation to sensing, networking support, localization, and planning tasks, based on user requests and changes in the environment. A specified quality of service should however be ensured for criteria such as resolution of the raw-data, latency, network reconfiguration delay, and resource utilization in the steady-state. This project develops an integrated cross-layered approach to networking, databases, control, mobility management, and information processing in WSNs. In particular, context-aware and energy-efficient solutions are pursued that are based on opportunistic sensing and processing techniques, dynamic indexing structures, novel query language constructs, reactive mobility control algorithms, and distributed compression based routing algorithms.

The technological advances from this research will significantly simplify the deployment of WSNs and lead to novel context-aware applications. The advances will directly benefit domains such as emergency-response management, environmental threat remediation, and biological habitat monitoring. Apart from developing the required algorithms, the project will implement simulation platforms and a monitoring environment using physical devices. The platforms will provide students with new educational opportunities to actively explore information acquisition and resource management in resource-constrained environments. All project resources will be shared with the public through a project webpage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed the challenges posed by the deployment and use of networks of fixed and mobile heterogeneous smart sensing devices to factor in competing demands on sensor network resources and their best allocation to sensing the environment and analyzing the sensed data. We developed effective and energy-efficient distributed algorithms for processing spatio-temporal queries with uncertainty in wireless sensor networks and designed novel spatio-temporal multidimensional index structures that adapt to topology changes and support efficient routing and query processing. Our work led to the creation of efficient context-aware application layer routing primitives and medium access control protocols that facilitate mobility and dynamic quality of service for time sensitive messages, while providing energy, delay, and throughput efficiency. Network coding and cross-layer optimization were explored, demonstrating effectiveness in a scenario of broadcasting a common content to a group of cooperating wireless nodes within proximity of each other. We also developed distributed resource allocation and mobility control algorithms that balance event localization, event response, exploration, and routing, and are robust to sensor noise and communication failures. We devised context-aware resource and power-efficient algorithms for important data processing tasks such as data aggregation, using Compressive Sensing to reduce the amount of data communicated and the efficient computation of discrete Fourier transform of data sensed on non-uniform sampling grids. Figure 1 illustrates the main collaborative aspects of the project across different context-dimensions.  

Specific examples of some of the salient findings of this project follow:

·We tackled the problem of security in geographical multi-path routing along paths corresponding to electrostatic field lines between source and sink nodes. This efficient and scalable solution to the workload balancing problem promotes a more even depletion of the energy resources among the participating sensors. This, however, enabled novel attacks, and we provided their systematic identification targeting different components of the protocol, along with a collection of defense mechanisms (cf. Figure 2).

·We developed novel couplings of physical and data-space abstractions to facilitate in-network indexing of sensed data, enabling both communication and storage-efficient processing of queries in sensor networks consisting of heterogeneous static and mobile nodes. Novel algorithms to handle changes in the abstractions due to mobility of the nodes, and trade-offs in (im)precision vs. energy consumption, combining rank order statistics, regular sampling, and bitmap representation were also proposed. Figure 3 illustrates the reconfiguration of the index and the relocation of mobile sensors.

·In heterogeneous mobile wireless sensor networks the sensor nodes need to move in order to efficiently gather and process information. To develop motion control algorithms, we mathematically described the cost of these tasks. In turn, these newly developed distributed algorithms iteratively drive the mobile sensor nodes to an optimal configuration while ensuring that queries about the data are processed with low latency (cf. Figure 4).

·We developed innovative data gathering and analysis techniques for WSNs that employ compressive sensing, distributed processing, and efficient routing techniques. In addition, we developed efficient cross layer routing protocols that exploit the context of the sensed information to prioritize the delivery of sensitive and/or important information (Figure 5 shows the schematics).

·Part of our efforts focused on developing efficient distributed predicate-detection techniques to model a predicate within a local region of the whole network, in a large-scale locality driven systems.

· In addition to algorithmic solutions and various hardware testbeds used to evaluate different findings, this project produced a simulator (SIDnet-SWANS) that can be programmed for variety of tasks: from mobility management and query processing, through testing various protocols, to testing different compression schemes and extensions of TinySQL– all able to monitor the evolution of the network and individual sensors. Figure 6 illustrates the interface of SIDnet-SWANS for spatio-temporal range queries processing.

This research has advanced the ability and scope of sensor network technology used to detect and monitor events in plethora of applications (surveillance, habitat monitoring, etc.) and provided a foundation for a unified approach to tackle mobility, uncertainty, data management, energy-efficient routing and data analysis/processing algorithms in sensor networks. Participation in this project provided invaluable experiences and training for many PhD students, as well as MS and undergraduates, several of whom were females and minority. These students will contribute to workforce in WSN-related engineering and technology and, in turn, will train others through their expertise.
